rename.from: `pytest==8.3.1` collects tests from Python dependencies within venvs (regression from `8.2.2`)
rename.to: `pytest==8.3.1` collects tests from Python dependencies within venvs unless `norecursedirs` is set (regression from `8.2.2`)

issue.title: Set `norecursedirs` in `setup.cfg` to avoid pytest collecting tests from our dependencies within our `venv`

labels.name: CI
labels.description: PR Category (used to generate the release changelog)

milestone.description: Note: Please refer to https://github.com/orgs/spinalcordtoolbox/projects/1/views/3 for a better view of this milestone.

repository.name: spinalcordtoolbox
repository.description: Comprehensive and open-source library of analysis tools for MRI of the spinal cord.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
## Description

With `pytest==8.3.1`, pytest will recursively search our `conda` environment unless we explicitly set `norecursedirs`.

## Related issues/PRs

Fixes #4570.

For upstream details, see:

- https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/12652

body: Does the venv directory contain a `pyvenv.cfg` file?

Yes! 

```console
# In root of project folder (where tests are located at `./testing`)
master|joshua@monarch:~/repos/spinalcordtoolbox/$ find . -name pyvenv.cfg
./python/envs/venv_sct/pyvenv.cfg
```
Interesting. Any chance you can poke the `_in_venv` function https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/8.3.1/src/_pytest/main.py#L370 to see why it fails for this path `./python/envs/venv_sct/`?

In a Python console:

```python
>>> from pathlib import Path
>>> def _in_venv(path: Path) -> bool:
    """Attempt to detect if ``path`` is the root of a Virtual Environment by
    checking for the existence of the pyvenv.cfg file.
    [https://peps.python.org/pep-0405/]"""
    try:
        return path.joinpath("pyvenv.cfg").is_file()
    except OSError:
        return False
    
>>> import os
>>> os.getcwd()
'/home/joshua/repos/spinalcordtoolbox'
>>> _in_venv(Path("./python/envs/venv_sct/"))
True
```

Exploring more on my end too... :thinking:

Hmm. On my local Linux machine, I get fewer errors. Windows specifically reports many more errors... so I might have to test on a Windows machine. See:

- https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/issues/4570

Just chiming in. We run automated tested in a docker container and on that container, we load the conda prefix inside the project folder. We could probably have done this better, but it was working for us in the past.

/projects/projectX: the git repository location
/projects/projectX/conda: the conda prefix

Since version 8.3.1 we notice the same issue as described above. Tests from included packages are being discovered.

With pytest 8.2.2: collected 190 items / 1 deselected / 189 selected
With pytest 8.3.1: collected 85611 items / 157 errors / 1 deselected / 29 skipped / 85610 selected

We solved it by adding to pytest.ini
```
addopts = 
   --ignore=conda
```

it seems like checking only for modern venv left us wanting for conda - is there a similar easy check we could do for conda prefixes/envs -- i'll reach out to conda on fosstodon to get input on fixing this, we might have to undo the steamlining for now

rename.from: `pytest==8.3.1` collects tests from Python dependencies within venvs unless `norecursedirs` is set (regression from `8.2.2`)
rename.to: `pytest==8.3.1` collects tests from Python dependencies within `conda` environments (regression from `8.2.2`)

body: For the record, I'm responding to @RonnyPfannschmidt reaching out on Mastodon (https://fosstodon.org/@ossronny/112837662322781627), we'll take a look at this ASAP.
@RonnyPfannschmidt Can you provide more details other than what was said here, which feature was added in 8.3.1 that triggered this?

issue.title: Investigate compatibility with pytest 8.3.1

labels.name: type::bug
labels.description: describes erroneous operation, use severity::* to classify the type

labels.name: source::anaconda
labels.description: created by members of Anaconda, Inc.

repository.name: conda
repository.description: A system-level, binary package and environment manager running on all major operating systems and platforms.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched open reports and couldn't find a duplicate

### What happened?

As @RonnyPfannschmidt [wrote on Mastodon](https://fosstodon.org/@ossronny/112837662322781627?kjy=spring):

> it seems like a recent [#pytest](https://fosstodon.org/tags/pytest) enhancement for detecting virtualenvs causes a [#regression](https://fosstodon.org/tags/regression) as conda ones are no longer accidentally detected (https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/12652) is there a easy way to figure if a folder is a conda environment to in-cooperate?

I'm opening this ticket to make sure we're following up to my first response in https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/12652#issuecomment-2246274332.

### Additional Context

_No response_

body:
Looks like #12544/#12545 is the culprit that reduces virtualenv detection to look for `pyvenv.cfg` only and effectively removes conda environment detection.

Given that we can't easily retrofit existing conda environments out there, and a significant number of users are using `pytest` within conda environments, I'd appreciate it, if you could revert the patch, or at least retrofit it with the previous detection mechanism.

issue.title: Support venv detection on Windows with mingw Python

issue.body:
closes #12544

- Updated the `_in_venv` function in `src/_pytest/main.py` to correctly detect Python virtual environments.
- Updated the test cases in `testing/test_collection.py` to validate the new behavior.
- Created a changelog fragment to document this improvement.

Here is a quick checklist that should be present in PRs.

If this change fixes an issue, please:

Unless your change is trivial or a small documentation fix (e.g., a typo or reword of a small section) please:

- [ ] Create a new changelog file in the `changelog` folder, with a name like `<ISSUE NUMBER>.<TYPE>.rst`. See [changelog/README.rst](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/main/changelog/README.rst) for details.

  Write sentences in the **past or present tense**, examples:

  * *Improved verbose diff output with sequences.*
  * *Terminal summary statistics now use multiple colors.*

  Also make sure to end the sentence with a `.`.

- [X] Add yourself to `AUTHORS` in alphabetical order.
-->

body: as per https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/12545#issuecomment-2246298479 - i'd slightly prefer adding explicit conda detection over reverting - in case thats not easy/feasible quickly we go with a revert
@jezdez so the key question - is there a easy foolproof way to check for conda explicitly - even if a `pyvenv.cfg` was not yet retrofitted

> @jezdez is there a good way to check for conda prior to that change? im happy to roll back for now, but if a consistent bugfix that ensures compatibility with older conda is easy, i'd prefer landing that over a revert dance

The best course of action would probably be checking for `path.joinpath("conda-meta", "history").is_file()` for now, as that's required to exist for conda envs to use the conda environment revision system (`conda list --revisions` and [`conda install --revision REV`](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/stable/user-guide/tasks/manage-environments.html#restoring-an-environment)).
working on a bugfix now, venv detection will be expanded to ("conda-meta", "history")
